DOC.HEAD: Farm Group Calls for Conference to Increase Food Aid to Eastern Europe
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the National Farmers Organization urged President Bush and congressional leaders Tuesday to work with farmers to increase agricultural exports to Eastern Europe. ``Food will assist Eastern bloc nations more than dollars and, at the same time, help the U.S. agricultural economy,'' said DeVon Woodland of Blackfoot, Idaho, a rancher and president of the Iowa-based NFO. Woodland said studies indicate that countries that received assistance under the U.S. Food for Peace program have become friends of the United States and developed into trading partners. The same cannot be said of countries receiving U.S. financial aid, he said. ``Why dollar aid when people in the Eastern bloc countries have no food available to buy? We are the richest and most abundant agriculture country in the world. We should use this food to, or at least a portion of it, for assistance to the hungry,'' Woodland said in a statement released by NFO headquarters in Corning. The group represents more than 250,000 farm families and markets farm commodities for its members. Woodland said food shipments to Eastern Europe would reduce grain surpluses, and thereby push up the prices U.S. farmers receive for their crops. He urged President Bush, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and members of the House and Senate agriculture committees to consider establishing a federal agriculture conference to help increase exports of food to Eastern Europe.
